awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ziling B Xue of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Tennessee is studying molecular magnets for their potential applications as a new generation of materials for information storage and quantum computation.  Such materials could have a much larger storage capacity than the current storage materials with significant energy savings and reduced environmental impacts. The goal of the research is to use spectroscopies to probe properties of molecular magnets to help design better materials in the future. The project is interdisciplinary covering inorganic, physical, and materials chemistries. It will offer graduate and undergraduate students opportunities to conduct research at national laboratories and broaden their educational background and training. Professor Xue plans to attract high school students who are potential first-generation college students from low-income families to sciences.

Molecular magnets demonstrate slow magnetic relaxations and quantum tunneling. Some such magnets have been shown to be candidates for chemical qubits. Research efforts have been mostly focused on design and preparation of the magnets with large anisotropies and slow relaxations. However, there has been relatively little understanding of the nature of certain critical properties of the magnets such as spin-lattice interactions, spin-spin interactions, and molecular dynamics. In this project, molecular magnets will be studied by several spectroscopic methods to answer the following questions: (1) Can variable-field and variable-temperature inelastic neutron scattering reveal magnetic transitions and spin-phonon couplings in molecular magnets? (2) Can the intermolecular interactions in the molecular magnets be probed by inelastic neutron scattering? (3) What properties in the molecular magnets can Raman and far-IR spectroscopies reveal? (4) How dynamics in the molecular magnets could be studied by quasielastic neutron scattering? The project could demonstrate that these spectroscopies could be developed into new methods to probe molecular magnetism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, molecular magnets were investigated for their potential applications as a new generation of materials for information storage and quantum computation. Such materials, if used in the future, are expected to have a much larger storage capacity than the current storage materials with significant energy savings and reduced environmental impacts. In contributions to intellectual merit, several advanced spectroscopies, such as far-infrared magneto-spectroscopy (FIRMS) and inelastic neutron scattering (INS), were used to probe properties of molecular magnets, revealing energies of magnetic excited levels in the compounds and the couplings between magnetic properties of the compounds with their vibrational properties (i.e., spin-lattice interactions), leading to relaxation of the molecules from the excited magnetic levels. The spectroscopic experiments also gave key magnetic parameters of the compounds. These studies advance the understanding of basic properties of the molecular magnets and are expected to help design better materials in the future. The work also demonstrated that the combined use of the advanced spectroscopies provides a comprehensive view of the molecular magnets and these spectroscopies could be developed into new methods to probe molecular magnetism.

Broader of impacts of the project include unusual opportunities for students to conduct research at national laboratories, broadening their educational background and training. Our publications have led to increased awareness of neutron scattering facilities and their potential applications for use in coordination chemistry. Through the project, Professor Ziling Xue and graduate students attracted high school students to conduct research. These students were potential first-generation college students from low-income families. Professor Xue also actively participated in other outreach programs, including hosting the visits of Upward Bound program at the University of Tennessee with the "goal is to assist the participants to successfully graduate from high school, enroll in college and earn a degree." In addition, he worked with the local American Chemical Society (ACS) section to host the "National Chemistry Week" program to the public.
